title: Co-op set to escape misconduct fines from regulators
text:
282.60 +1.35 
Bank's fragile capital position is likely to see it avoid a heavy fine from regulators at the Financial Conduct Authority and the Bank of England's PRA 
The Co-operative is set to escape a heavy fine from Britain's two main financial regulators investigating the near collapse of the lender two years ago. 
The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) will avoid imposing a punishing levy on the bank for fear of worsening its weak capital position, according to sources quoted by Sky News. 
The regulators are due to formally announce the findings from of an 18-month inquiry into the bank's conduct on Tuesday. The FCA refused to comment on the speculation. 
Last month, the Co-op hinted it was ready to enter into settlement talks with the watchdogs. 
• Could this mark a fresh start for the Co-op Bank? 
“The FCA and PRA [Prudential Regulation Authority] have indicated that their preliminary view is they are minded to make findings against the bank covering certain decisions, events and processes over the period from mid-2008 to end-2013. Based on their current view, the FCA and PRA have indicated they intend to commence formal settlement discussions in July 2015," said a company statement. 
Financial regulators have used their powers to impose heavy levies on lenders in the past. In May, Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) was hit with the biggest UK bank fine in history over its role manipulating the foreign exchange markets. The FCA ordered Barclays to pay £284.4m but the scale of such a punishment is unlikely to be levied at the Co-op for fear of threatening the bank's precarious recovery from a series of setbacks and scandals. 
In 2013, the Co-op was found to have a a £1.5bn hold in its finances, triggering a series of scandals which saw the bank’s former chairman, Paul Flowers, embroiled in criminal investigation into the purchase of Class A drugs - earning the ordained minister the nickname “the crystal methodist”. 
The bank has since overhauled its governance structure and is now just 20pc owned by the Co-operative Group following its rescue by a group of hedge funds (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
